topic.title: HPE Helion OpenStack 2.0: Removing a VSA Node

body.p:
This process is used when you want to remove storage system/VSA node from a cluster/management group for maintenance using HPE Storevirtual Management Console(CMC). After maintenance the VSA node is added back to the cluster.
To have the volumes available even after the VSA storage node goes offline, you must ensure that the VSA network RAID configuration/data protection aspects are taken care prior to removing a VSA node.
See Using disk RAID with Network RAID in a cluster, Planning the RAID configuration, and the Data protection sections of HPE StoreVirtual Storage Online help (available in StoreVirtual Management Console) before configuring RAID. You must configure RAID before adding the storage system to the management group. Refer the online help of HPE Storevirtual CMC for configuring the network RAID for storage systems. link required...
You must set the Data protection level while creating the volume type for the VSA volumes in Openstack Cinder. The volume type extra spec for setting the data protection is hplh:data_pl (link not working) for HPE LeftHand/StoreVirtual storage. For more details refer Openstack Cinder configuration guide(Kilo) for HP LeftHand/StoreVirtual driver.

section.title: Removing VSA Storage System for maintenance
section.p:
Perform the following steps to remove VSA storage system for maintenance:
Review Determining volume and snapshot availability section in HP StoreVirtual Storage Online help and ensure that the volume is available if the storage system/VSA node that is planned to remove for maintenance goes offline.
If the repair option is available for the VSA storage system, choose the appropriate option in repair. For detail, refer to Using Repair Storage System in HPE StoreVirtual Storage Online help in CMC.
OR
If the repair option is unavailable, perform either of the below operations to remove the VSA storage system for maintenance:
Refer Maintaining storage systems in clusters section in HPE StoreVirtual Storage Online help in CMC and perform any of the below operations to ensure that the cluster functions normally and the volumes continue to be available even after the storage system is removed/replaced.
Add and remove storage systems for an existing cluster (The new storage system from the list of available VSA storage systems as shown in CMC).
Exchange a storage system in a cluster.
Removing a storage system from a cluster (provided the remaining storage system is sufficient for the data availability, a minimum of 3 nodes should be available after the remove operation). Once the maintenance is done, the storage system may be added back to the cluster. Follow the instructions for "Adding a storage system to a cluster" to add the VSA storage system back to the cluster.

p.note: While removing VSA storage system permanently, the operator needs to ensure there is odd number of managers running to avoid split brain syndrome. For example, if there are five nodes and one node is getting removed the operator needs to stop the manager running on any of the remaining four nodes

title.b: Exclude the VSA node that's offline(removed for maintenance purpose) for further reconfiguration/updates until it's back online

section.p: Even after the removable of a VSA node, it should continue to remain in data/servers.yml file. It is also recommended to create a servers.yml file on the deployer node with a list of VSA nodes that are currently offline so that these nodes get excluded from any further reconfiguration or upgrades. This prevents a VSA node that is offline from being included in deployments.
The format of servers.yml file would be !<VSA node-name>*
where VSA node-name matched the interface used to access this node during deployment. For example!padawan-ccp-vsa001* (VSA host as given in hosts/verb_hosts)
When performing Helion lifecycle management deployments specify the name of this file in a --limit option to prevent the deployment process trying to access the VSA nodes that are offline.
Execute the following command ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts osconfig-run.yml --limit <hostname>
For example: Adding "offline-vsa" to the VSA host name ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts osconfig-run.yml --limit @offline-vsa
Run the following playbookansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts hlm-deploy.yml -e elasticsearch_cluster_name=hlm-001 --limit @offline-vsa

title.b: Remove VSA storage system from cloud

section.p: You can remove the VSA storage system from the cloud after it is removed from cluster management group in CMC. This is done, if you want to remove VSA permanently.

Perform the following steps to remove the same cluster which has been removed from CMC in cloud. (How do u remove cluster in CMC?)
Delete or comment out the VSA system information at /home/stack/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/servers.yml .
Commit your configurationcd ~/helion/hos/ansible git add -A git commit -m "Remove OSD node <host-name>"
Run the configuration processor:ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml
Use the playbook below to create a deployment directory: ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml
Verify that the node is removed from hosts/verb_hosts file. (command to verify?)
